captions.text:
Well forcibly marry me off to a fish if it
isn&#39;t a second Lovecraft-themed detective

game by an ambitious midrange developer in
as many years.

One where the main character is a generic
detective even more generic and detective-y

than the one from Dark Corners of the Earth
and the intention is not to adapt any specific

Lovecraft work but mash them all together
into a big ball of tentacles and faint undercurrents
of conservative social anxiety.

But will the Sinking City be an improvement
on Call of Cthulhu?

Well, it&#39;s by Frogwares, who since 2002 have
been utterly cornering the market on slightly
janky Sherlock Holmes adventure games.
Remember Creepy Watson?

Yeah, that was these lads, so imagine what
they can achieve now they&#39;re deliberately
trying to be creepy.

It&#39;s nice to see Frogwares finally managing
to step outside their comfort zone of developing

detective games based on late nineteenth century
literature, and instead develop a detective
game based on early twentieth century literature.

And it only took them seventeen fucking years
to make the jump.
Outstanding.

At this rate, they&#39;ll be adapting modern literature
roughly around the time of the heat death
of the universe.

This week&#39;s haunted detective protagonist
is Charles Reed, who is drawn to the titular

Sinking City so that he might understand his
strange visions of vast apocalyptic horrors

beneath the sea, unsatisfied by the explanation
of too much convenience store sushi on an

empty stomach, and quickly finds himself tasked
to investigate various crimes and disappearances

surrounding the apparent fulfilment of a doomsday
prophecy.

Now, the thing about Lovecraft&#39;s particular
brand of horror is that it doesn&#39;t really

translate to modern attitudes, even without
the racism stuff.

Cosmic horror was all about challenging humanity&#39;s
self-importance.

The horror of Cthulhu lay not in Cthulhu wanting
to nibble off our knackers but in the fact

that Cthulhu doesn&#39;t really give a shit - he
was around before humanity, will be around

long after and spares us no more thought than
he would the dust mites in his bathroom carpet.

But that horror doesn&#39;t work so well in the
modern age when we only need open a web browser

to be reminded that humanity is pointless
and deserves to die out and leave naught but

cheap plastic Spider-Man Halloween costumes
for the archaeologists of future races to
puzzle over.

So Lovecraftian horror requires a different
approach to be effective these days.

And whatever the ideal approach is, it isn&#39;t
whatever the fuck Sinking City is doing.

You know how in the Shadow over Innsmouth
the fact that the townspeople worship Dagon,

are turning into fish men and routinely knob
Deep Ones was the big horrifying revelation
that drove the narrator mad?
Well Innsmouthers show up in this game.

Someone points them out and says &quot;They look
weird, don&#39;t they?

It&#39;s because they worship Dagon and are turning
into fish.

Besides that they&#39;re alright lads but I wish
they&#39;d stop flooding the local economy with

all that gold they get from those Deep Ones
they&#39;re always knobbing.&quot;

It just throws me how everyone including the
protagonist takes all this in their stride.

The game has a rather insipid combat element
as partial justification for the open world

so every now and again we get attacked by
reject Silent Hill Homecoming monsters in
a basement, and no one seems to give a shit.
&quot;Yeah, pesky buggers, aren&#39;t they.

We kinda got used to them after we barricaded
off the seven or eight streets they hang out
on.&quot;
I&#39;m sorry, how many streets?
What are the fucking cops doing?

Shooting at me, apparently, because I got
confused and briefly pointed my gun at a deranged

heavily tattooed Deep One cultist as he walked
nonchalantly down the street to the chemist.

There&#39;s something very surreal about Sinking
City.
That&#39;s the point, Yahtz.

I mean surreal more in a janky design than
a horrific way.

Let&#39;s get that out of the way now - it&#39;s not
scary.

It has more the vibe of a noir thriller about
organised crime where all the factions are
based around Lovecraftian monster cults.

Which rather undermines the inevitable Lovecraft
game sanity meter.

We lose sanity as we fight off a basement
full of spindly monsters, but not when we

go report back to the mutant fish man who
gave us the quest as he gurgles &quot;Dammit, I

keep telling those cultists next door to stop
leaving their interdimensional harmonizers
on.&quot;

Not that the sanity mechanic makes perfect
sense otherwise.

If it gets too low we get attacked by delusional
monsters, fine, but it comes back by itself

so fast it hardly matters, I just make Charles
Reed stare at the nearest wall for the ten

seconds it takes for him to come to terms
with humanity&#39;s place in the universe.

As I say, it&#39;s a very janky game, made jankier
by the attempt at open world gameplay.

Random NPCs appear in the streets, as in,
literally materialise before your eyes, occasionally

hovering a foot off the ground and taking
a mysterious interest in blank walls.

Perhaps I&#39;m not the only one with a sanity
meter.

And the open world sandbox has the usual bad
sandbox issue in that it&#39;s mostly there to

pad out the game with extra travel time where
nothing much happens and the environments
aren&#39;t varied enough to make it interesting.

There&#39;s a lot of copy pasting going on, especially
with the interiors.

Think we won&#39;t notice if you just move the
furniture around, do you, Sinking City?

Well making more than three sofas might&#39;ve
helped.

Having said that, I do like that location
markers for places of interest aren&#39;t added

automatically, and that you have to add them
yourself from vague street directions.

In fact, I generally like the detective mechanics
overall, you can tell this is the comfort

zone of Frog &quot;Sherlock Holmes versus Megatron&quot;
Wares.

The stories are nicely worked out, I like
the way we physically combine facts to draw

conclusions in the Memory Palace - grand a
title as that might be for a boxy menu screen,

I could make a fucking text window in Microsoft
Access and call it Ali Baba&#39;s Cave of Wonders

but I&#39;d only be fooling myself - and I like
how we have to research cases at the library

or the newspaper office to fill in important
details, &#39;cos that&#39;s, y&#39;know, what an actual
detective does.

I just wonder why the newspaper office is
still running when half the city is underwater
and the other half is reenacting The Mist.

The game I&#39;m most reminded of is Silent Hill
Downpour.

For it, too, made the fatal mistake of trying
to do psychological horror in an open world

with sidequests, when in doing so they relinquish
control of the pacing, and pacing is what
a horror story lives or dies on.

Sinking City just doesn&#39;t grasp pacing at
all.

There&#39;s a bit where you put on a diving suit
and descend into the depths beneath the city,

arriving in a surreal world of twisted alien
ruins where krakens as big as conservatively
sized office buildings drift by in the background.

This, Sinking City, is the sort of thing you
do at the end of the game as we discover the
full extent of what lurks beneath.

But this is in the first fucking chapter,
and afterwards we just pop straight back up

to the city going &quot;Blimey, bit weird down
there, isn&#39;t it.&quot;

And we go back like, five more times over
the course of the plot just to completely
demystify it.

&#39;Cos the first time, I was like &quot;Oh shit it&#39;s
a kraken, there&#39;ll be no salvaging these underpants.&quot;

And by the end I&#39;m like &quot;Hello, Mr. Kraken,
don&#39;t mind me, just cutting through your yard
again.

Oh, here&#39;s your tupperware back, thanks again
for the cup cakes.
How do you get them so moist?
Actually don&#39;t answer that.&quot;
